A longshort position is a bet in the spreadprice changes between two equities. It profits if the spread of positions increases long gaining value relative to the short and loses money if vice versa. It is not a bet on the nominal value of Apple or Microsoft individually over time. I shouldve been more clear. The recommendation is not a bet that Apple will go down. Its a bet that Apple will go down relative to Microsoft.

This doesnt automatically mean they are the majority While not a definitive measurement, it is a little easier to gauge the majority or at least plurality opinion on a subreddit due to the karma system and peoples tendency to use it to upvote what they agree with and downvote what they disagree with. So if were just focusing on a single subreddit, the opinion most visible is oftentimes also the most popular opinion and not merely the loudest. Of course there will be exceptions, but the karma system does push popular opinions to the top. Thats not going to be true everywhere though, and crucially, whats a popular opinion on a subreddit wont necessarily be a popular opinion with the general public.

Heres the issue Tesla isnt actually growing. Their quarterly revenue is down every quarter this year, and essentially flat with with revenue this time last year. They havent been bringing more money in, or appreciably growing any of its businesses. Their products are profitable, but its not correct to say they are growing. Instead, Tesla has been cutting costs significantly to offset this lack of growth, as well as getting significant carbon offset credits. The issue is the former is a temporary measure, at best, to increase the short term profits, but has severe consequences downline as you May ah be left without the staff to grow at all. The second is a concern because this isnt a sustainable product. Im not knocking him for using them, but a pretty significant portion of the profits this quarter are roughly 13 are purely from an unsustainable source. This is not good news for the future. For all intents and purposes, Tesla is looking to sell just as many vehicles this year as last year, and revenue only marginally better. They are.increasing profits, but this is likely due to cutting costs through labor and the like, which can have severe downline impacts on growth. In short, as of right now, there is no reason to claim Tesla is a growth company. Its barely growing. Its finding creative ways to increase profits on its revenue, but this is sustainable for only so long.

replies.text: Alright, this is not as deranged as I thought it would be reading the title. Still, this bet has been the bet for value investors for literally 20 years. AI is just the latest buzzword, before that was metaverse, cloud, whatever. Is this the tipping point? Maybe? But history has taught us that betting against the major players has been a losing bet Now your conclusion is certified rstocks nonsense. Small cap isnt a single company, it doesnt make any sense to group them together and say they can use AI to improve their margins from 3 to 10

1 I think this if AI does drive significant productivity improvements, then labor heavy businesses will benefit from improved margins from using these products that large tech companies are offering is worthy of a separate discussion. There are going to be longerterm beneficiaries beyond just owning tech. That said, I think these beneficiaries are definitely going to be more specific than owning indexes. This thread also goes into all the reasons why AI has disappointed while talking about beneficiaries it doesnt seem like youre that confident in the ability to deliver on the end products when it comes to AI. 2 I think the timing is very difficult. I dont disagree with what youre saying in regards to spending and Ill admit that I thought this cycle would be a giant version of smaller previous NVDA cycles and it still probably will, but on a longermuch longer time frame than Id expected. Yes, mega cap tech is spending hundreds of billions of dollars on this. No, shareholders dont really care yet and what does it take to change so many peoples one investment playbook from basically own mega cap tech? I dont know and to try and predict thatcall the top because one thinks its an eventuality without any indications of things starting to erode is going to lead to disappointment. So, I dont disagree with some of the things you mention but the specifics are tough I do think that theres an interesting conversation about AI beneficiaries. I talked about VST early this year on here as an AI beneficiary and the response was crickets because it was like nobody wanted to hear anything AIrelated that wasnt tech. Mag 7 have had a good year, but things that are beneficiaries of all that spending NVDA primarily, but things like VRT have had a better year imo. I mean, two of the top performing stocks this year are utilities that have mooned because of expected energy demand. I think that there are potentially interesting discussions on peoples guesses for beneficiaries in terms of productivity and theres not enough discussion on here of whats being impacted call center software FIVN clearly not a beneficiary. ADBE is struggling. Jumping into something like small cap value may be a better investment starting soon although theres nothing that I can see that would indicate that or the way things are going this could easily go on for another couple of years.
Arent GOOG, AMZN, META, TSLA trading under their average historical PE ratios?
Someone remind me the last time small capinternational has outperformed US indexes?
A very sobering post and I think youre correct in just about every part of your analysis
Cloud and AI are legit solutions. Metaverse was unsubstantiated bullshit. Cloud and AI solve real problems
Still, this bet has been the bet for value investors for literally 20 years Every Value Investor, every year, for a decade

Going off past history doesnt always work here. I know one company in particular here is most likely gonna trade with a brick on its head for a good long while due to the DoJ. The next bear market has a half decent chance of being the secular bear that some have been waiting for TBH.
International19992009. Small cap For most of history the small cap value premium has been very strong, the past 15 years have been a significant outlier.
I definitely get that. I was just a bit confused on pointing to PE ratio as a point to make if nearly 50 are under their norm.

What would it take for small cap to outperform? BidenHarris greatly increasing antitrust regulatory pressure I think. Weve seen US megacorps grow extremely powerful, and it doesnt seem like anything else will change that.
All it would take is large cap not performing and the extremely high levels of earnings growth that investors are pricing in.

I really think that large cap has made their businesses into untouchable monopolies, and corporate lobbying has made new competition much more difficult. Not to mention the habit of simply acquiring competing startups. The acquisition part is no longer an option under the current administration, but unless they go further, I really do think large cap market share is untouchable.

Also there are 3 mRNA vaccines in phase 1, 1 mRNA vaccine in phase 2, and 0 mRNA vaccines in phase 3.

April 17, 2007 Sanofi pasteur, the vaccines division of the sanofiaventis Group, announced today that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration FDA has licensed its H5N1 vaccine, the first avian influenza vaccine for humans in the U.S. Sanofi pasteur, in collaboration with the National Institutes of Health, submitted a Biologics License Application to the FDA for this H5N1 vaccine. The licensure serves as a first key step in achieving the governments goal of stockpiling vaccine intended to protect those who are at increased risk of exposure to the H5N1 influenza virus contained in the vaccine during the early stages of a pandemic. Source FDA Licenses First U.S. Vaccine for Humans Against Avian Influenza

Thanks! Did you know that Novavax claims to work on a bird flu vaccine? I have asked them multiple times by email to clarify that this isnt the same vaccine they announced and abandoned 1520 years ago and what their new approach is. After all this cant be about the Sanofi vaccine in combination with MatrixM, because that wouldnt require any work. But they never responded. They are probably too busy firing scientists and making plans for the new pipeline. Novavax continues to optimize preclinical candidates, including a new approach to H5N1 bird flu vaccination. Novavax also confirmed earlier in the month that its currently conducting a preclinical study for an avian flu shot Novavax, which has been conducting preclinical tests on vaccines targeting three different H5N1 strains, rose 5.3 per cent to 15.70. In a prepared statement, Novavax told the Financial Times that its vaccine platform could be an attractive asset from a pandemic preparedness perspective because the currently available avian influenza vaccines produce limited immune response.
Covid is still rapidly evolving and therefore requires updated vaccines, similar to influenza. Covid vaccination rate is about 20 in US adults, compared to 45 for influenza.

Yeah, i am not sure either, but I can only imagine its extremely difficult to identify a causation nearly two years later. Maybe it is possible, but seems unlikely to me. Youre certainly right, the FDA has more information than us, so maybe it is warranted. They like to act out of extreme abundance of caution, so I am sure that is the culprit. Again youre right though, it will either impact both companies or neither. Although, the potential impact is much more for novavax than Sanofi.

I worked for a competitor of IBM for years, so I acknowledge my bias. That said, I found IBM to be a kind of cult to many customers in the 80s and 90s, and a few even now. At first, enterprises looked at IBM as the Cadillac of computing. They locked in many places with their mainframe computing the IBM 360 was a staple of business. The biggest places had sales staff with personal relations to the C level of enterprises and sole sourced the equipment. UNIVAC, DEC, Tandem and others to a lesser extent. As the 80s and 90s rolled around, Big Blue kept high prices on their Cadillac and although they rolled out their UNIX AIX and virtually invented the PC, the pricing was high, proprietary in an open source minded world and they lost market share. For one retail company, the Bd of Directors required competitive bidding, and even though any competitor could provide less price and equal or superior function, IBM would be awarded the work because we are used to them. Finally others stopped bidding the pointless exercise it was just to press IBM to keep their pricing down. When the old guard retired, and the enterprise realized the premium they paid for obsolete proprietary systems it was too late. They still used the IBM OS2 PC into the 2000s. They went from sales of billions to bankruptcy. I am convinced their cult belief in IBM and failure to modernize contributed. I did a study for multiple companies that illustrated if they moved off the bloated AIX systems to competitive systems, they would save millions. The paradigm shift always seemed risky, but those that moved were well rewarded. In the last 15 years, where IBM competed against Dell, HPHPE, Fujitsu, Amazon, Microsoft and others for data center refresh, cloud and other updates, they rarely stood the test, unless it was from one of those cultist enterprises who had decided before the bid. They still have a mainframe market it is expensive to migrate but not impossible. Their database product , PC, AIX and others are considered by most to be old iron. Even their cloud is a bit proprietary and pricey iron cloud. Watson has been discussed Their quantum computing research is admirable but given their history of trying to make things proprietary so they can keep price and margin high, I wont expect it to play well with others. It is vaporware somewhat. All said, their sales and margins and employee count are down to 23 of the numbers 10 years ago. The legacy of arrogance. I vote thumbs down. FWIW.

Enterprise Value is usually a better metric for the cost of buying the business than market cap because it takes into account the companys debt and its cash. Enterprise Value Market Cap Debt Minority Interest Cash. If a company had a 500 million market cap and 500 million debt and 50 million annual income, it wouldnt be any better value than the company with 1 billion market cap, no debt and 50 million annual income. The first company would have a lower PE ratio but both companies would have the same EVEBIT ratio. Because it also adds minority interest, you should divide by EBIT rather than earnings because EBIT doesnt have the minority interests share removed. Plus, its available in most stock screeners, including TradingView. TlDr EVEBIT is a better measure of value vs other metrics such as PE.

He said that wrong by referring to 50M income instead of 50M EBIT. What EVEBIT does is strip out the effect of how a company is financed. Say you have two companies both with the same EV 1B and the same EBIT 50M. One of them has no debt, so its 1B market cap and pays no interest costs its net income will be 50M minus whatever taxes it pays. The other one has 500M market cap and 500M debt, so its net income will be 50M minus interest costs minus taxes. They may have different PE ratios based on the interest and tax regime but the important thing to understand is that underneath they are the same operating business just financed different ways. So you have to evaluate the two things separately quality of the business how the business is financed.

The dot.com bubble was very different. Not to say that valuations could be stretched at this point. I was old enough to do the dot.com. Right around 30. I know way too many companies that were basically three card monty. Sucking up VC money. Padding sales data when they showed up at the offices. Pipeline stuffing. Also, essentially we will buy X or advertise c on your platform if you do the same with us. Just shuffling VC money around the room to look like platform had interest or their was sales. I wouldnt doubt there are probably some companies like that now. But that was so much about infancy. This is not infancy. This is massive corporations with massive earnings and cash hoards throwing that cash at being first movers ... its that important. It would be idiotic for the meta nvda msft types, downstream chip players and fabs, software value add players, to be burning through their cash as they are. They know history. They know what is playing out here. Having used ChatGPT for a myriad of things, my wife the same. I have been learning prompts, she just learn as you go, we are stunned at the impact on our lives and then I read and see what else is happening that makes what we are doing silly. When companies like msft are throwing down 125B on a single datacenter as an example. You just dont do that on hype. This race is critical to corporate survival and global balances of power. Hell even China is creating a regulatory body to ensure we dont end up AIing wwiii with all of it. Tech companies are readily letting people go, hiring at lower salaries bc AI is changing the landscape for standard computer science guys. Just look at the silly things your person at home is doing on social media with AI tools. And then imagine what the players are doing with the best minds and engineers in the countryworld. We havent even started to speak to timelines on healthcare and processing data regarding studies and time to insight on drug candidates. Learning is going to be accelerated by magnitudes and at speed we cant fathom. Things will be needed. Necessity is the mother of invention. It doesnt not fail. Power sources will be uncovered. People had been far and happy for a while. No more. Another anecdotal cliche, publish or perish...translation keep up and get it done or disappear.

I would disagree with that. The current promise of AI is that it will revolutionize the back office processes in basically every company. Companies will become thousands of times more efficient when all of those millions of dollars they spend on paying employees to readwrite spreadsheets, PDFs, Microsoft Word docs, etc will no longer be necessary since AI will be able to do it in a blink of an eye. This is almost certainly technically possible and will happen to one extent to another. This has the potential to automate everything else.

replies.text: This looks like a Chatgpt post. With AI and advertising, it is not about growth but better targeting thus, they can increase their rates. I am longtime holder of META but their ad targeting has gotten poorer in the last six month I cannot tell you how many ads I get for California or Florida restaurants but I live in NJ. Either the ad placer does not know how to use the tools or they are poorly designed.

Maybe what Im about to write wont answer your questions, but Im someone that works in an advertisingmedia agency as a motion designer here are some of the things Ive seen Our media tool can consolidate information about the audience a lot better. Strategists dont have to spend as much time looking for specific data now that Ai can find some of the patterns much quicker. Ive also seen them create the target market persona pages using Ai. There is still a lot of human input required to create a working strategy, but Ai has sped up the process. Take this section with a grain of salt since its not what I interact with the most, just what Ive heard from friends. Creatively, Ai has mainly sped up a lot of the behind the scenes work. Pitch theater if you will. I used to work in an agency in which art directors were photoshop gurus and could mock something up to elevate a concept. That is now a thing of the past, generative Ai can do that so much quicker. Its not perfect, but when youre trying to just pitch something internally, Ai is more than good enough. Also, why use stock images when you can get Ai to create much more custom imagery to represent your idea. Its not uncommon to use Ai as the foundation and then incorporate photoshop to truly hone the visual. All in all, you dont need as many people to be part of pitches now. When we hire external production companies I now see countless Ai images. A production company had one of their character concept artists run their 2D drawings through Ai to show how they would look in 3D. These were still flat images, not renders, but I was incredibly surprised by quality of mock. You wouldve NEVER gotten to see 3D visuals of a character before getting client approval on the concept art, but with Ai you can now accelerate things that were further down the pipeline. Copywriting. I mean, not much to add here. Long scripts and ideation still gets a lot of love from my coworkers, but the quick tweets and captions that they used to hate, thats Ai work now. This is probably simplifying A LOT of things, but I cant deny that Ai is already altering the workspace. Mainly by making everything move a lot faster, and if there is one thing that advertising clients LOVE, its fast. The pace of advertising has always been relentless, and in some way, Ai has come to both alleviate and exacerbate the problem. If your agency can produce more ads that target more people, you can bring more clients. The industry has changed and many clients are doing one off projects instead of signing annual contracts with agencies, but thats not to say agency of record is not a thing anymore. An advertising agency is not just selling individual ads, its selling a whole suite of creative and strategy services. If Ai can be successfully integrated into this service to cut timelines and budgets, you better believe clients will flock to that agency.

Ive worked in digital marketing for years and AI had been around well before the huge AI spend. Companies like Meta, Alphabet, Amazon will continue to bring huge amounts of cash due to how much AI helps advertisers with targeting. Meta has benefitted the most so far since they have shown the market their AI investing is resulting in more revenue from advertisers who are happy with Metas AIdriven targeting capabilities. The use case for AI in advertising is clear and pretty straightforward. The question is whether the spends will justify better products and services in other areas that companies can then sell for more money. Right now the answer is no pretty much across the board.

Ive seen waves of disruptive tech get invented, rolled out, innovated and commoditized over the decades. The past shows us that speculators will invest like lemmings and the market will shake out the chaff. AI has promise in advertising but who will develop the secret sauce and win? It kinda reminds me of Internet ecommerce 25 years ago. The investments in various companies created a market bubble that burst at the investments outdated the reality....ecommerce evolved to what it is today over years. I remember when Amazon was touted as the next big thing, but had failed to earn a profit in its life. The stock never grew until 2011 when it caught on. AI seems the same, in fact a bit of a bubble that needs to break and regrow to the AI solutions that prove themselves. That takes a bit of speculative investment and vision.

the big four will be the most likely winners, but it wont be due to increased efficacy. Theyll say it is, just like they did last go around which wasnt particularly true. The value prop before was how cheap it was targeting. not sure AI will help in either instance, since AI can also be used to muck up targeting. TLDR AI probably wont be as massive of a boost to profitability as web 2 was. Well, unlessuntil we all start living in VR.
Is there a path to where it doesnt cost a lot? Like improved heuristics or advances in computing? Or even advances in energy?
Nothing presented so far can justify the current spend in the name of AI. It is still a word for most industries at this point.

Its not about increasing their rates but rather the AIs better targeting leading to a higher return on ad spend by companies that results in them spending more money. Meta and Google are the best bang for your buck on advertising. They are very cheap and you can target exactly who you want.
No, this absolutely does not look like a ChatGPT post.
Your points are all very valid. One note though is that all you mentioned saves money vs. makes money saving money is limited and capped by your current spending.

It would just get tricky if you are actively monitoring each very closely and are able to get emotionally swayed on short term upsdowns. Longterm it would depend on what exactly your risk profile is. In an ideal scenario everything booms and you see colossal gains, but on average your likely to see less than ideal results. Given the time and effort it sounds like you have put into it, it might be slightly more ideal to you than any other index, but your timeeffort doesnt matter to the market. If you have 1015 stocks making up a large percentage of your portfolio, I might consider reducing the smaller impact ones, or at least reducing your effort with those. Might makes sense to employ some type of threshold to make each investment more worth your time. EG. either make your all of your gems worth it or reduce your footprint to your top tier gems.

there is no absolute best answer here. Tradeoffs in both directions for different things. People that say having X is too many are just making it up. The SP500 is literally 500 stocks and outperforms most people over the long run. A good rule of thumb though is dont hold more stocks than what you can keep track of. Instead of just dumping everything into an index fund you could go with a Core Satellite portfolio. Basically the gist of it is your biggest holding is some kind of an index fund which makes up the core of your portfolio. And your satellites are individual stocks that you feel good about being able to outperform the market with. Your Core holding will ensure that you dont get too beaten down if your satellite stocks do badly, while your satellite stocks can ensure that you still outperform the index if youre good at picking them and investing in the right time. This is the philosophy that I follow for my investing. Also Ive actually reduced my number of holdings as my portfolio has gotten bigger, and just made bigger more concentrated bets on my top picks, for a lot of the reasons that you mention. I do think that with my limited time it helps me track my portfolio much better. And with a core holding of VTI it helps address my concerns about lack of diversification due to all of the sectors that I dont invest in because of a lack of understanding of them.

An easy way I use to gauge performance is I have the portfolios highest value and portfolios lowest value for each year, average that out. Then I backtrack out the net deposits from the total for the year and compare it to last years total and it gives me a general CAGR. In a single year it may be off, compared to the arbitrary rule of choosing portfolio value on Dec 31st. But over multiple years it balances out to being very accurate. Now that Schwab is my broker it actually just gives me a return performance that adjusts for deposits. Its the one good thing I like about Schwab.

I was wondering if I can do a simulation of hypothetical scenario where I had simply invested in index, saving me enormous time in research. If so, please suggest toolssites? If you have data in excelspreadsheet, XIRR is the function you are looking for. In one column you will get all your depositswithdrawals, and lastly final value of portfolio. Mind sings. In the second column you will have dates for this transactions. XIRR will give you your avg return. For other part of the question, in next columns you can simply calculate what return would be from pure index portfolio. As if you just buysell some ETF on any given date and what would be final value of this hypothetical portfolio. Make fist column with historical value of given index fundse.g. INDEXGOOGLEFINANCEIndex ticker,price,date,2,2, second column for count of shares that would be amountdepositswithdrawals divided by previous column.. Sum of this will give you total number of shares, just multiply it witch current index ETF price and you have your total value of portfolio you could have. If you already have data in excel or can export it from broker it is quite easy job. I find this simpler as third party tools, but it less flashy. It can get little tricky when you are dealing with multiple currencies, but not impossible.

Thats easy enough to figure out, just time consuming to do the math. Step 1 Select an SP 500 index fund that youd have invested in instead like VOO. Step 2 Look up a chart listing the opening and closing price of said fund every day the market was open over whatever time period you were investing I use Yahoo Finance for this, but Im sure theres plenty of other options that have the same data. Step 3 If you dont already have it, track all of your individual buys and sells of your stock in a spreadsheet. Step 4 Add some columns in the spreadsheet for assuming you bought into your SP 500 index instead with the same dollar amount. Be consistent, like using the closing price of your index on that date unless you just so happened to also buy into that index on the same day, in which case you can use that price instead. Step 5 Now that you have the number of share youd own of that index see how the number tracks compared to your real world outcome. I find this to be a very helpful exercise for me. I tend to consistently under perform the index in the year I buy into stocks, but then a lot of those buys tend to outperform the index in later years as I continue to hold.

except its much more complicated than that? NVIDIAs moat is both CUDA and hardware but there are other indirect moats for example, ML frameworks integration with CUDA is strong Pytorch, Tensorflow, JAX and open source models such as ONNX and ONNXRuntime are sort of heavily influenced by Microsoft. Its not as simple as creating an ez software layer when Sagemaker and Vertex AI have been around for quite some time now. Besides, CUDA and cuDNN is not even in the software layer. First, they have to be able to create an incredibly efficient chip for both training and inference, second a CUDAequivalent, third to steer ML frameworks to force it to adopt a new nonCUDA architecture, fourth is to force researchers and developers to develop new models catered to the new hardwares alongside all dependencies, etc. People who hasnt trained complex models or created them or deployed them are so uninformed about how tightly integrated NVIDIA is to everything. Tech moats are a different kind of moat. Integrations are one strong thing in tech. And NVIDIAs moat is just incredibly complex. Companies that serve AI products will have to redesign their huge pipeline, redo bunch of their codes, retrain some models, etc. when a new nonCUDA thing and nonNVIDIA hardware happens. Moreover, NVIDIA is now working on building more efficient GPUs that can take on TPUs which are actually a pain in the ass to use when training models based on personal experience
as they should be
at this point, think of OpenAI as one of Microsofts arm.

LLM Leaderboards are useless to me at this point in telling which is good or not. The benchmark process is still broken IMHO and there will be more research about how to gauge them better since these are new things. Most application uses anyway such as assistants, chatbots, etc. are finetuned versions anyway, some even using opensource applications. My personal thinking is that Google is gonna bottleneck itself with their own TPU hardware sooner or later as they are either gonna fully commit to it or just suddenly pivot using NVIDIA again similar to their switch from Qualcomm to Tensor G1G4 with Samsung fabs to TSMC moving foward. They will, however, be perpetually contending within the leaderboards for LLM although my personal favorites leading these would still be META and OpenAI for different reasons. GOOG has a personal motivation to do it tho since they have the Google Assistant thing which is probably their biggest usage of this in addition to GSuite additions. Bottomline, pick GOOG for software reasons but never because of their TPU advantage.

I tried bard and I can feel the significant gap trailing ChatGPT back then. Then I tried Gemini and feels wow, its a lot closer, and now with extensions to my email and workspace. I have always thought that Google AI relies on Nvidia gpu since they also bought it for their cloud customers. This TPU finding is surprisingly hidden even for a typical google fan like me. Added things like google deepmind and pioneering research leading to transformer, the Gemini AI progress now multimodal is very encouraging. I for one encourage competition so that users like us can benefit. I can feel that Google is now leading the AI race but they are just humble. If I were Sundar, I would have directed all TPU compute toward Gemini already.

claude is trained on a combination of aws Trainium and Inferentia chips and google cloud. With that said, its very encouraging to see Gemini that is solely trained on native TPU can catch up not too far behind the AI race.

Because Claude and Gemini are both Google Products. And TPU is only available within Google Cloud. So ofc, they are gonna use TPUs lol. Its all about not being constrained with one cloud provider. AWS itself is way better than GCP right now with more mature products. AWS Sagemaker Google Vertex AI. Im an AI Engineer and training with TPUs are a pain in the ass. Way behind support on ML Frameworks versus CUDA. Current NVIDIA Cloud GPUs like V100s, A10G are still way more efficient and costeffective than TPUs for inference. Dont bank yourself with Google and hardware. They have a poor track record when it comes to hardwares that they create.

This was him 4 days ago Google is such a hideen gem, it has much lower marketcap than Nvidia and everyone is only Nvidia this or Nvidia that but no one ever mentions Google, they are so massive you dont even need to invest in an ETF because they are an ETF.

I purchased close to all time high so it was around 353800 since then I have averaged down and now its 3 contracts. My average is 2500. Currently down 2700. Its why I always buy a minimum of a year and a half out. Give myself some time. Anything under a year seems way short.

But how did a company that has been apparently working on these things for more than a decade turn into a company that is seen as a lagging? Why did they just implement AI into search after the whole OpenAI hype making them look as if they are playing catch up? Nevermind the missteps they had. I dont know the products you named but do they generate revenue?

Not an FI, and I am a long term investor but only on things I understand thats why my portfolio is like 60 ETFs and about 30 individual tech stocks since I have spare money and Im fine with high risks. I dont hold any of AMD and Google just because I am still incredibly confused as to what their goals are. Personally I dont think Google will outpace NVIDIA and they are two different companies. Google is software and Nvidia is hardware CUDA which isnt really a replicable software. Googles direct competitor is Microsoft and somehow META. I just think that Googles software side is incredibly replicable and that the shift from perspectives that their sales are gonna go from ads to AI will have a tough time. On the software end, I got Microsoft or even META. META just because Gen AI tools is going to be extremely connected to their biggest shtick which is content creator platforms, and the fact that META, IMHO, has the best AI research team. FAIR has been producing the best AI papers for the past years most esp in computer vision. People dont know that things such as Magic Eraser, Magic Lasso Tool root itself from METAs Segment Anything which is the most ground breaking thing in Computer Vision alongside Diffusion Models. Microsoft too have strong integrations with software from Teams to MS Office suite and Windows. Most underrated is Github and Github Copilot. They literally own a shit ton of free code to train LLM models. For AMD, I am not so well versed on their products. They wont be able to compete with NVIDIA some time in the future. Honestly, if I were them, I would just try to completely dunk on the sinking ship that is Intel and fabricate CPUs that tightly integrate with NVIDIA GPUs on cloud clusters i do have a local AMD Ryzen laptop with RTX i use for local small training of models. Current virtual machines right now still have Intel NVIDIA GPUs e.g. V100, A10G. If AMD will just focus on beating Intel instead of NVDA, they could just win the AI race alongside them. If NVIDIA gets tired of Intels bullshit, I can see them fabricating their own CPUs. NVIDIA will still be the strongest contender by a mile for atleast 57 years. I cant see anyone coming closely to rivaling their moat until then. Even if a war breaks out in Taiwan and new chips halt in production for some time, the remaining functioning data centers can still function IMO. One company that I suggest worth looking at is definitely Qualcomm. They are trying to enter the desktop space and making the edge device phones, etc. much beefier to have its own Neural Processing Unit that are capable to run multimodal models. As phones get better in that, they have less need to access cloud servers which in turn means less need for GPU servers NVIDIA. Although Qualcomms direct competitor at that space is Apple which is gonna do the same. I am not an FI, but as an AI engineer, I am bullish on NVIDIA. I would definitely think that it is quite overhyped by people right now because it has been an AI arms race and every one is trying to race which AI product will be the first to profit. The purchasing will slow down. However, believe it or not, we are just scratching the surface for what AI can do. Diffusion models are just only around for about 3 years, LLMs for 2.5 years, and we havent reached those breakthroughs to the traditional AI real money makers yet such as detection and reinforcement learning but I have a feeling that it will come out sooner. But the thing is that comparing it to crypto is crazy because AI has business use cases and profitable as long as it has the proper market. NVIDIA is just creating more data centers to keep up with the cloud service demands from AWS, Azure, etc. but even if the demand gets low, they can always sell the access to services for cheap and still get money from it. But who knows, thats the free market for you.

I very much agree to the software side. A lot of useful google services embedded as extension to Gemini are helpful such as maps, workspace, photos on drive etc. Honestly at this point I cant no longer distinguish, on a meaningful level, between the performance of chatgpt and Gemini AI. Thats just me as a normal user going about daily googling and searching.

Innovators dilemma ? Why would Google want to be the first to put out AI results when its more expensive to generate those results AND less amenable to showing advertisements. But yeah, they could have led with that in their Cloud division.

Wow thank you. Ive been on Reddit for like 18 years and this is among the top 5 responses Ive gotten to an investment question. I really appreciate this thoughtful answer. Im surprised to learn that Meta has the best AI research team. Theres a lot of people out there doubting Metas vision for AI. Good to know from an expert like you that they are a strong contender. I hope you post more in this subreddit, we can all benefit a lot from your insights.

Risk, guardrails, ethics. OpenAI had nothing to lose if it said hitler is Jesus on twitter, they are open source and researching! Google does that to kick off the llms in the public stage? Stock loses 10 overnight and congress eyes them. Thats just one short justification but Im eating chili and dont feel like typing

Metas vision for AI I too have doubts with the MetaVerse thing. But its the YahooGoogle scenario where you lose more by not investing to something that booms rather than investing and gaining nothing. METAs AI strategy is in fact weird. But the open source AI community has shown that opensourcing models such as METAs own LLM as well as SegmentAnything have better benefits to some extent. METAs FAIR have been producing papers such as SegmentAnything, DINO, video understanding, etc. They have Yann Lecun whos one of the godfathers of AI. Imagine a model that parses the image you uploaded and understands the skirt you are wearing, the bag you are carrying, the place you are in, the kind of coffee you are drinking, the style of dress you have, etc. This is groundbreaking in terms of advertising. They already have models that can do that. Whether they are already implementing it in the background, I do not know. They also have really great papers on 2Dto3D reconstruction which can be ridiculously good for MetaVerse.

Imagine a model that parses the image you uploaded and understands the skirt you are wearing, the bag you are carrying, the place you are in, the kind of coffee you are drinking, the style of dress you have, etc. This is groundbreaking in terms of advertising. Im very interested in this, since my company does some facebook advertising. This would indeed be a game changer. Are they close to getting this right? Thank you for the extensive and thoughtful comment.
Atleast the models already exists for both scene understanding and image parsing. Whether they have been already using it in the background, I do not know. Haha!

replies.text: You dont see it when you look at the revenue, but UpWorks growth has been declining and pretty much has come to a halt. Gross services volume is basically the same as it was a year ago. Revenue is only up because they keep increasing the take rate. 19 of what the clients pay now goes to UpWork. Their revenue guidance for Q3 is less than what they made in Q2. So they might enter a phase of negative growth now. Caused by declining usage which cannot be offset by further increasing the take rate. They keep focussing on enterprise deals and neglect the marketplace experience. Although the marketplace is the 6x bigger business. Clients who use the marketplace still get 3 ! invoices and receipts per week ! even if they just work with one freelancer. Who wouldnt want to add 19 to their freelancer cost and the hassle to add 12 documents per month to their tax paperwork? TlDr They focus on their sales team, neglect the product, make it more and more expensive, usage growth declines. They still have a great starting point as the market leader in work marketplaces. But unless they change the approach, I think nothing will come out of it. If the business slips away, my hope is that a new, more product oriented CEO will come into play.
Assymetric to the downside.
Ive been on Upwork for years It is straight ass these days

Thank you for sharing your thoughts. I do agree that there is still work to do, however, the take rate is much much lower compared to Fiverr. I do think the invoicing part can be improved, I know theres a giant project in regards to the VAT calculation.

Im not saying the increase in take rate is necessarily bad. But it is also not what can make up for a decline in users in the long term. Fiverrs market cap is 30 smaller than UpWorks. So it is not a proven way forward that can be a role model for UpWork. Also their business is different. Average spent per buyer is 4x smaller on Fiverr compared to UpWork. When you commission a onetime job like a logo, it doesnt matter if you pay 100 or 130. That wont make you take the job off the platform. But when you work with a freelancer on a constant basis, you start to think about why you pay UpWork every month too. Because the only thing you get for it is the invoicing. And when that invoicing is done super badly 12 monthly documents instead of 1, 4 monthly payments instead of 1 you will think hard if you really want to continue using that service.

In my opinion, UpWork is there not only to connect the freelancer with the client but also to provide trust. it ensures that if the work gets done, the freelancer gets paid. In case of any disputes, an UpWork representative steps in. Taking a contract outside of UpWork is against their terms and conditions unless the fee is paid. Yes, clientsfreelancers can agree to continue working outside of the platform. However, if theres a dispute at any point in time, one party will be unsatisfied. In addition, both parties are back to square one, the client needs to find a new freelancer, and the freelancer needs to find a new client.

True. They offer more than just invoicing. Still the invoicing is done badly and that hurts a lot. Im not sure the other services make up for it. And currently the numbers make it seem that the concept is not working. Gross services volume was about 4B in 2022, about 4B in 2023 and might be even lower this year. Is there reason to expect that this stagnationdecline will stop and turn into growth again?

I focus on the long run, and there I expect Increase in the number of freelancers Demand for freelancers to increase UpWork has reported an increase in enterprise clients. This isnt much reflected in the revenue, and I have a feeling this is due to the terms offered. I wouldnt be surprised if they have a free trial for a certain period, that doesnt generate any significant revenue for UpWork in the short run.

Where can we see that the number of freelancers and the demand for freelancers are increasing? On UpWork, there have been 872K active clients in Q1 and 868K in Q2. Thats a decline. I dont see that they reported an increase in enterprise clients. Where can I find that info? All I see in the investor presentation is enterprise revenue. And that also declined. From 26.6M in Q1 to 26.3M in Q2. Despite them spending 47M on sales and marketing in Q2.

The active clients is an important metric. However, comparing Q2 vs. Q1 is misleading due to holidays. Every year, there is decline in Q2 vs Q1. Instead, compare it vs. Q2 the previous year. The enterprise number was mentioned in the earnings call, and is also in the 10Q report. Lastly, the sales and marketing is decreasing over time allowing for higher margins. This is not only for the enterprise clients, but for all.

I dont see the number of enterprise clients in any of their documents. What is it? Maybe you are referring to their number for new enterprise clients? That does not tell us if the overall number is increasing or decreasing.

Yes, indeed, the new enterprise clients. This number in Q2 is higher than in Q1. However, I do not focus too much on this, given that the size of the enterprise clients isnt disclosed. This is why I find the active clients a more relevant number.

So the numbers tell a clear story, right? Usage growth has died down to zero. As seen in gross services volume and active users. And with the guidance of 6 revenue for Q3, it stands to be expected that usage will start shrinking now. Despite over a hundred million Dollars spent on sales and marketing per year. My interpretation UpWorks service is good at the beginning of the user journey. To match buyers and sellers. But then it becomes a chore. Because of the weekly invoice cycle and the separate invoicing from sellers and UpWork. That makes it an 8x worse solution than direct seller to buyer invoices. UpWork gained a massive amount of users during covid. And now those users abandon the service. Its a long way down to precovid levels. It can make the business decline for years. On the upside, UpWork might have the potential to become as big as the other market place leaders. Amazon, Uber, Booking, AirBnB, Shopify etc are all orders of magnitude larger than UpWork and I dont see a reason the leading work market place shouldnt become as big as those. But I think that would require a shift in the way UpWork is run. As the current approach to growth is not working. As can be seen in the numbers.

I am not sure if the invoicing would change, and to what extent. If you are a freelancer, it is good to be paid weekly instead of monthly. As for the user growth, it isnt actually declining. The of active clients is growing. Last year, they announced a change in their fee structure. It used to be multitier 20, then 10, then 5. So, the larger the contract, the lower the fee UpWork takes. The new structure is a flat 10 fee for all. I do think some contracts were taken outside of UpWork, which led to a reduction in the average spend per client which is reflected in the Gross service volume decline. I do think this is temporary, as with any price increase decision made.

The 0.46 in active clients they reported in 2024Q2 is not active clients in that quarter. But in the last 12 months. So I dont see a reason to think that is a seasonal effect. In 2023Q2 it was 0.6. In 2022Q2 it was 1.77. So basically what the number tells us is that they lost more clients in 2024Q2 than they won in 2023Q2. Still, the 6 active clients YoY look kinda good, so if those would be the only numbers we have QoQ and YoY, I would say I dont know what to think. Lets wait until next quarter. But we also have the guidance of 6 in revenue QoQ. The worst guidance in the history of UpWork. And they explain it with negative trends in the topoffunnel which could mean active clients or spent per client I think and expect it to continue We did see those trends get slightly worse in June and July And they talk about working on anticircumvention efforts in the call. You can find it in the transcript. Which should mean they will try to stop buyers and sellers from leaving the platform once they have found each other. Why would they have to do that if their users wanted to use the invoicing service they provide? The users dont want it. I dont think you can grow a business by saying We have a good service and a bad service. We give you a good service for a few days and then well force you to use our bad service forever.

And on chip power delivery to get that battery life up past 8 hours and it will likely run cool and compete with them on all fronts. Youre right that YoY growth is a really bad metric to value a high PE stock, as is comparing this quarter this year, vs the same quarter last year. For me to buy a stock with a high PE, it better have higher revenues and higher earnings every quarter and those numbers better have a strong correlation to each other and to EPS those boxes are checked. I like to look at quarterly revenue and EBDITA I have plugged in the numbers, and I would argue that these numbers are both statistically linear. The revenue numbers do a fit a parabolic fit better than a linear fit, hinting at slowing revenue growth. But, the parabolic fit will always be better than the linear fit, whether or not it has meaning, and quarterly earnings reports make for very sparse data. Im expecting roughly linear but moderating revenue and EPS growth and will unload if there is a big surprise to the downside. With linear EPS growth for the next year out, earnings for the next year would be 23 times higher, making the forward PE, which ignores analyst estimates, very reasonable. Growth will probably moderate because of supply chain constraints and moderation in demand. But, Nvidia doesnt need a PE close between 20 and 30 a year out at these prices because highgrowth market leaders always command a PE premium. But, its very plausible that revenue growth is slowing because TSMs production capacity is a bottleneck and it takes a long time to build new fabs, which TSM is doing. However, Nvidia has historically kept its margins very high when there is strong demand. I think the pertinent historical examples are the last bitcoin bubble preASICs and Cisco around its nosebleed peak with a PE over 200. During the crypt0 bubble Nvidia absolutely crushed it while reddit gamers had daily tantrums about Nvidia charging unfair prices for their GPUs. That lasted until ASICs made it unprofitable to mine with an allpurpose GPU, crypt0 started crashing and Nvidia crashed. Im watching Mag 7 cap ex because Cisco collapsed roughly the month after its biggest customers like Worldcom, ATT, AOL, Qwest, and Sprint started dramatically cutting their cap ex. The now bankrupt Worldcom was an outright criminal fraud that was buying Cisco routers to pretend that they were making money to pump their share prices. So Im worried about demand, Im worried about ASICs, respectively thinking about Cisco and the last crypt0 bubble. The main reason I bought more AVGO because its price is down and because OpenAI is building a new secret chip with Broadcom, which is almost certainly a new ASIC chip that will rely on Broadcom and TSM. Also, broadcom should benefit from its auto and manufacturing chips and cell phone sales will probably pick up if rates go down and its a given that they will go down. But, major risks are that the economy is definitely slowing by almost any metric and the Fed is always late with their rate moves, with their backwardlooking data analysis, and whats bad for the economy is bad for everyone. Also, from now to October is historically a very bad time for semis and Wall Street knows it. Also, we know that if investors revolt on spend, CEOs like Zuck will dramatically cut back on cap ex, like he did after the Metaverse crash. I think if one megacap CEO cuts back on GPU spend, they all will, as I feel they are defensively spending to not get left behind, so the script can flip and growth can turn into misses in a hurry. Finally, I feel that most semi and software stocks are overvalued and catching AI tailwinds for no reason and this will hurt the few stocks with good performance, because hedge algos will work to keep correlated pairs of stocks correlated. The conflict between Iran and Israel could blow up in the near future. Also, the performance of bigger and bigger transformers could hit a wall, but I dont think theres evidence of that yet. I dont think humans are special and that there are intrinsic limits about what humans can do and future AI cant. However, better GPUs will someday be locked down even in the U.S., as a national security issue. But, I have a longterm horizon, and the megacaps that are pumping money into NVDA havent cut back on cap ex yet. Nadela says there is still increasing cloud demand and the probability that he is telling truth is greater than the probability that he is lying. I can afford to be wrong about the future and Ill still pay a lot of taxes when I exit.

replies.text: Of course the big banks are going to recommend alternatives, theyre the highest fee product they sell. I read an article about the Harvard endowment recently and how theyve lagged behind public equities for a decade. Theres supposed to be an illiquidity premium for investing in private markets, but apparently all theyve gotten is illiquidity and no premium. If they indexed instead, not only would they had done better, but they wouldve payed less fees in the process. Private markets and alternatives are the new hot thing on the street because now retail is gaining access to it. More money flooding in will probably mean that illiquidity premium youre supposed to get will be less. Also, net of fees youre probably right around public equities and maybe even less depending on the manager. Im not saying not to invest in it, just want you to be aware of some of the risks. I personally wouldnt allocate more than 20, but for me, when the crowd is going one way, I usually go the opposite way

My main alternative investments are in wine, whiskey and crypto. I do have a few collectibles. For the wine and whiskey, I use Vinovest. Youre right services like this have made these assets far more accessible to the typical investor. They are no longer just for the super rich.

David Swensen, who pioneered these alternatives approaches, much followed by the institutions you cite. Thought most people should be less actively involved and mostly should be watching their fees. Specifically, the access to private alternative funds is limited for the average retail investor AND those investments they can get to, have their earnings results eroded by excessive fees. The most important difference, in terms of categories of investors, is between those who can make highquality active management decisions and those who cant. Pioneering Portfolio Management is for those who have the ability to manage portfolios actively. Unconventional Success is a book for the overwhelming number of individual and institutional investors who cannot manage a portfolio actively. Almost everybody belongs on the passive end of the continuum. A very few belong on the active end. But the unfortunate fact is that an overwhelming number of investors find themselves betwixt and between. In that inbetween place, people end up paying high fees whether to a mutual fund or a stockbroker or another agent. And they end up with disappointing net returns. And, Im old enough to remember when most institutional investors didnt even have small cap or nonUS investments, let alone alternatives. So, small caps, nonUS, and emerging markets were, once, alternatives. Then high yield and global bonds were alternative. So, whats an alternative? Whatever wall street wants to package and sell you for a fee, regardless of return potential So, what do i invest in? PE? Typically follows returns of the small cap market, without the lockup or fees of a decent small manager. So, Im 25 small today based on valuations. Vanguard strateq. Private Credit? You can find loan funds, like Eaton Vance or Invesco. Not today thanks, sold it off from last year, and sold off hy when spreads went super tight. Are long bonds alts? Real estate, are my own properties. Others should maybe use vanguard reit index. Hedge funds? Nope. Crypto. A 5 allocation to a diversified etf because, fkit.
What are your preferred alternative investments? oldschool PE How much of your portfolio are you putting into alternative investments? anywhere between 10 and 15 I would say

Thanks for sharing, I think thats a solid perspective. Ive worked in an alternative investments throughout my career, mostly in commercial real estate. Id say there was definitely an achieved illiquidity premium where I worked, but also the real estate market during that time was performing incredibly well so obviously my experience is anecdotal and maybe it was strictly a timing thing. That being said Ive talked to a bunch of investors in some of these alternative assets I listed and reviews are mixed. But yeah most people I talked to that are in fundrise for example seemed to be worse off net of fees. I would love to read that article you mentioned if you find it and wouldnt mind posting the link I would appreciate it.

Yeah I think thats pretty solid advice. Ive talked to a bunch of people that invested with Fundrise for example and the fees were a little heavy and returns were disappointing. I think having an expertise in a niche, obviously makes a huge difference

LLMs are just one type of AI. There are also a lot of Machine Learning ML models that are doing very well and rely on Nvidia chips. Image processing, for example has done very well in the past 1015 years. You know that picture you took with the phone? A lot of the processing is done through MLAI models. A lot of medical devices also use this technology to improve images and remove noise. Natural language processing NLP is another you know how some systems progressively get better search results the more you use it? It uses some type of ML algorithms to learn. Sensor processing is another different one. A lot of our smart watches uses ML technology for algorithm development. ML and AI has been doing very well for a very long time, and a lot of it is hidden to the general public. LLMs are just the one that has the most visibility right now because most people dont really understand how fundamentally ingrained it is to our daytoday lives. Almost all highend technology we use these days has some data science team working on some type of algorithm that uses Machine Learning.

Walmart, Target and Amazon already have been using AI to optimize their ordering and logistics for years. It is not perfect but takes a lot of tasks off of the human who used to do it manually. Self driving cars isnt what you would expect as Amazon had done it with their warehouses. They use a selfdriving robot to move the entire shelf to a human for picking, instead of having humans run around the warehouse for picking. There isnt going to be a big overnight change as people would have imagined but rather slowly replacing humans starting from tasks until it could replace the job entirely. Likely the Internet didnt change how we lived during the dot com rush but fast forward to today, the Internet fundamentally changed how we live. AI would unfold similarly, but faster and greater than the Internet IMO. We just cant predict who is going to win from the AI revolution, just like no one thought a website that sells books in the early Internet age would become one of the largest companies on earth today.

So the hype is real and pervasive. I also work with AI on a daily basis software engineer and I feel the same as OP it simply cannot do what all the hype is saying. Now as it affects investing theres a lot of money changing hands based on AI promises, so yes there is a bit of a bubble. But I believe there wont be a sudden burst of that bubble....so many companies have made significant investments into their AI infrastructures that theyll be able to pivot into more useful things when the truth about AI capabilities or lack thereof sets in. It wont just be a bunch of money lost, but they will have to redirect their resources. Yes, there are some acquisitions happening today including where I work that wont pan out in the end, so thats money lost but only for the acquirer, the equity owners of the acquired company have converted their equity into cash, which flows back into more investments, more companies, purchases in the economy, etc. So while I do believe theres a bit of overvaluation in the market based on AI hype, I dont think there will be a sudden bubble burst. It will be a slow correction, IMO, and might be marginalized by all of the other factors driving market movements, and therefore not even noticeable. IMO investing to bet against AI wont make you rich. You could make some money, yes, but probably wont be a huge win. Here is an example I asked chatGPT a specific technical information regarding a product Whats the electronic viewfinder refresh rate of a sony a6400 camera? The answer The Sony a6400 camera has an electronic viewfinder EVF with a refresh rate of 60 frames per second fps. Further question can you do it on a6300? the answer Yes, the Sony a6300 does offer an option to increase the electronic viewfinder EVF refresh rate. You can choose between two refresh rates 60 fps default 120 fps high To change the EVF refresh rate on the a6300 Go to the Menu. Navigate to the Setup tab. Look for the option labeled FINDER FRAME RATE. You can select either Standard 60 fps or High 120 fps. The higher refresh rate of 120 fps provides a smoother experience, which can be beneficial for tracking fastmoving subjects. However, it may consume more battery power. Now whats the real answer? Taken from the review website The A6400 inherits the same 2.36 million dot OLED electronic viewfinder from the A6300, which features a 120fps high frame rate setting to help track moving subjects more smoothly with virtually no lag. Further communication I think you made a mistake, because A6400 features the same EVF as the a6300 and it seems thier refresh rates can be adjusted both to 120fps. ChatGPT fallows up Youre correct, and I apologize for the confusion. The Sony a6400, like the a6300, does indeed allow you to adjust the electronic viewfinder EVF refresh rate to either 60 fps or 120 fps. To adjust the EVF refresh rate on the a6400 Go to the Menu. Navigate to the Setup tab usually represented by a toolbox icon. Find the Finder Frame Rate option. Select either Standard 60 fps or High 120 fps. The 120 fps setting provides a smoother viewing experience, particularly useful for tracking fastmoving subjects. However, keep in mind that it might lead to increased battery consumption. So yeah, all that hype for something that can bullshit you with the straight face....

So, heres my personal thought on this. And this is after watching an interview with the CEO of Google DeepMind Demis Hassabis In the short term, AI is overhyped because people are saying it will soon be able to do all these amazing things, and Hassabis says the same thing. AI is advancing quite quickly, with the next big thing being AI agents that can complete complex tasks for you, like an assistant. But thats not going to be in the short term, but moreso in the longer term. Im suspecting 45 years, personally. And that will be a big deal in terms of the tasks it can do for you. But we are not there yet. And this is similar to what Hassabis says, where longterm it may be underhyped but personally I think longer term it is just hyped. I think when companies are able to get AI agents to work, it will hit its stride. Want to also mention, that in an interview with Squawk Pod with Andy Jassy, the CEO of amazon he talked about AI, and the investments amazon is making on 3 major macro areas. One of them being for companies wanting to train their own AI models. And another for companies wanting to use existing models developed by other companies and amazon themselves. So, personally. I think we are still in the short term. Companies and developers are still learning about AI and how to make something concrete with it. Things like chatgpt and Gemini are amazingly impressive imo, but companies have not fully crystalized a way to monetize these tools and learn how to actually use them. Im looking longterm, and the companies investing in AI will benefit, assuming they make the right decisions on how to integrate with their business. But it will not be immediate, and it wont be an immediate spike in businesses but a gradual increase.

If customer A has a defect rate of 0.001, then I would argue 100 visual inspection is not needed, or at least is a waste of time. Those resources would be better spent on preventing the defects in the first place. We use an image recognition station at work to check if a glass plate is properly compressing a gasket. It works fantastically. If you really need to train an AI for a low defect rate product line, then intentionally make the defects on that product line. They dont even have to be good units. They could have something else wrong with them. You could make only the section being inspected, etc.

Case B I agree, but arent you missing the point in case A, Sorry if Im wrong since Im not an AI developer and havent dive deep in AI and machine learning probably not even the surface, but shouldnt you in case A, train based on nondefect data? You cant possibly train on defect data which in reality would be very few hence would be useless. Imo you should train with the image of nondefect which is abundant and try to recognize if its nondefect. To recognize a defect doesnt mean you need to train with defect data, you could just train to recognize nondefect with nondefect data, and decide if its a defect.

I think there is truth to your comment, a lot of companies have got caught up in the hype around AI. Check out Gartners Hype Cycle of 2024. The risky financing behind technology has gotten out of control, and the ability to profit from it has become more about hype for a new technology than about profits or applicability to real world problems. It is a completely circular sales cycle where a technology generates hype, gets funded, and then the VCs are covered through financing offered by float from cloud service providers that see more volume in service consumption. It is all just a dance where we are running compute cycles for no reason except to prop up investment in a tech startup whose primary value is consuming more cloud services. AI is the final cycle of this because it gives you an excuse to consume a ton of resources to train these models, and not have to worry about the business effects of what these models can actually deliver until you are finished. It sounds like you or your customers might be applying the wrong or suboptimal ML approach to solving these problems. For dents on an assembly line, simply placing cameras in a fixed position should give you the ability to collect data on the distribution of parts. You can then simply plot the deviation of your data and use classic anomaly detection methods. Cracks can be detected using basic edge detection, and erosion techniques. Machine learning would come in if the part placement relative to the camera shifts around for whatever reason. For example if you wanted to extract a mask or bounding box of the part as a preprocessing step. You can even use a model like Florence to generate embeddings and measure the distribution of the embeddings from data coming off the assembly line. For memory leaks, finetuning or an alignment oriented technique like DPO might be helpful

I see AI as very analogous to the internet during the early dotcom boom. It is very clearly a powerful technology that has worldchanging ramifications but it may take a while before we figure out the best way to leverage it and create all the necessary groundwork. I dont think AI is overhyped. Actually, I think people largely dont appreciate its full potential. However, it could still be another decade or two before we fully reach that point. When we do, however, the world will be a very different place. It will be at least as large of a leap as the internet ushered in. If youre too young to remember needing to consult an encyclopedia or filling out an order form to mail away for something you may not fully appreciate the extent to which our lives have changed postinternet and you may not realize that it all started with a 2400bps dialup connection to ASCII message boards. Thats about where AI is right now somewhere between proof of concept and marginally useful in certain applications. 20 years ago the idea that a computer would be able to recognize a random image of a cat was virtually unthinkable. Now it can not only identify a cat it can nearly instantly generate an new image of an American Wirehair holding a sparkler while flying over Mt. Fuji in a wingsuit. My programming IDE autogenerates about 25 of my code out of thin air with zero effort on my part. These are HUGE leaps, and theyve occurred very quickly. The problem with AI is really just consistency. Something that fails 510 of the time isnt particularly useful in most cases even if the results most of the time are mindblowing. But that error rate will improve with additional training. More importantly, however, is that the learning algorithms are still being refined. Very soon we may be able to reduce the required training data sets by several orders of magnitude, for example. In the short term the AI bubble may or may not burst the way the dotcom bubble did. But, long term, I expect it to be a fundamental force in virtually all aspects of modern life just as the internet has now become.

The fact that LLMs are trained on so may different fields of knowledge is part of what makes LLMs, to me, seem transformational. Recall that many of the breakthroughs in science and technology throughout history have come from combining disparate ideas from multiple disciplines and synthesizing something new. So the existing LLMs out there are very powerful tools. Full disclaimer I have a subscription to Claude.AI, and often use it as part of my work or for helping me learn. But my point was that while hardware will definitely improveand with improved hardware we may also see opportunities for improving softwareas you said, were reaching the asymptotic limit of what we can do with language and with a language model that essentially operates as a next word or next phrase predictor. And until we figure out a better theory of mind, what we got now is more or less it. That is, were going to have to shovel in more and more stuff in there for very small incremental improvements in intelligence. Its an amazing tool, and I do agree with you that it does have the power to transform our economyonce folks figure out the right ways to apply these tools. For me, I use it as a means to get some crossdisciplinary insight, which is fascinating. But as I noted before in my downvoted remarks LLMs are starting to reach an asymptote where the improvements are slowing down and becoming more incremental rather than fundamental. ... And it will require a fundamental rethinking of how AI works to move past where we are now. For example, Id love it if someone working on CoPilot would consider somehow marrying it with a toolset that can do dataflow analysis, semantic flow analysis and a method for onmachine code analysis such as variable usage as part of the underlying model. Meaning Id love it if CoPilot would not make stupid errors, like suggesting code that calls routines that are misnamed or that are guessed at, or calling out using variables that do not exist or are named differently.

Oh, I have no doubt GPUs will improve, and Im sure well see neurochips and other technologies roll out which make it possible to run large model LLMs on ever smaller and less energyintensive platforms. I personally would like to see the day when we can roll out a smallscale LLM that runs on a Teddy Ruxpinlike toy that can run enough of an LLM to hold sophisticated conversations with small children that can run off two Ccells. But from a software perspective the improvements were seeing in LLMs seem to be less fundamental and more incremental. In part, were simply hitting the limits of the philosophical theories of language and intelligenceor rather, the presumption that intelligence is strictly a linguistic construct rather than is based on an understanding of the world that is deeper than the symbols we attach to that meaning. Or, framed another way, LLMs currently do not have a model of the world or a model of how the world works essentially they predict the next word or collection of words that would go in a sentence as a response to an input collection of words. Its why there are so many examples of LLMs getting basic math wrong, or why we see things like CoPilot write shitty software because there is no understanding there. Just the manipulation of symbols. And the people currently working on the next generation of LLMs are essentially operating on the theory that if we could just shovel more shit in there, well get smarter LLMs. My own theory is that until we have a better theory of mind than the ideas from philosophical linguists, were only going to see very minor incremental improvements in what is already out there. Sure, itll be less energy intensive and eventually we may even see it run locally on portable devices. But it wont be smarter. And we already know that the way the human mind processes information is not just linguistic in nature. For example, at my alma mater, work was done to identify the clusters of neurons in the human brain that drive our ability to recognize faces. That is, you dont learn how to recognize faces after youre born from some sort of tabula rasa instead, there is builtin hardware inside the human brain which handles this recognition, and that there is a finite number of these clusters may go towards explaining why Dunbars number seems to exist.

Because LLMs fundamentally cant do what OpenAI et al claim they can and more compute doesnt change that. Without a paradigm shift that allows models to actually know things and have a concept of truth and falsity, they cant do anything more than what they currently can.

What youre describing is a fallacy that has propagated rapidly in the last 5 years in regard to the usage of AI. The terms common meaning used to have at least some reference to a cognitive science sort of reasoning, about a machine that could think in a selfreferential way something like consciousness. I dont know when, but in the last few years the term AI has come to mean absolutely nothing about Artificial Intelligence, and has strictly come to mean a model that is more competent than humans at something, and General AI has come to mean a model that is more competent than humans at most things. Thats it. I think youre astute to observe this has all happened before. And Generative AI is no different its just becoming thing computer do. The whole AI thing is just how business types sell products that do nothing useful.

What youre describing is a fallacy that has propagated rapidly in the last 5 years in regard to the usage of AI. Blame John McCarthy who coined the term in 1956. I think youre astute to observe this has all happened before. Well, it helps that I was there. Or, more specifically, my interest in Artificial Intelligence came about in the early 1980s when I was in college and read the works of John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky and Claude Shannon. The second programming language I ever learned after BASIC on a TRS80 was LISP and my high school science fair project was building a primitive theorem prover which could solve basic problems in propositional calculus. Which, at the time, was considered Artificial Intelligence, but now is just a fascinating parlor trick done by nerds with too much time on our hands. Edit to add for those interested, the works I used to help me with my science fair projects were Patric Winstons Artificial Intelligence first edition and J.A. Robinsons Logic Form and Function.
