Pew Research and the OECD have many studies g reports that show average US people losing their standing in the world. Is the quality of life getting worse, of course not, like the rest of the world we take advantage of technology innovation and efficiency, but the US is no longer the best place to live for an average citizen. Were just not superior to the other top counties, as we used to be. Given the enormous size of our economy we should be. The examples of corporate welfare are plentiful. The biggest is healthcare. Consider that the biggest government expense is healthcare Medicare, Medicaid, VA, active service, ACA, employees, contractors employees, etc. The US federal government is the biggest buyer of healthcare in the world, but pays more per unit person, drug, etc than any other government. These prices could be negotiated down, but industry influence prevents that. FYI the Medicare drug negotiation that is much talked about today is a deception. The three drugs I checked all go off patent in 2026, the year the negotiated price comes into effect. In effect not costing big pharma anything. Eliquis, a drug used by someone I know, is more expensive in the US, the largest customer of it, than in any other country. The primary goals of ACA were two fold, lower prices and cover more people. More people are covered, but US prices continue to run wild. KFF, Kaiser Family Foundation has great studies of healthcare costs and effectively across the world. The US spends 34 times more for healthcare than the average of other developedrich nations. Other examples of government overpaying include military and even the broadband subsidies. The US pays 4 times more per fighter jet and Russia or China. It might be a better jet, but not so much better that one is more effective than three of theirs. The US has among the highest broadband Internet costs in the world. Too many poor and rural people cant afford the high cost. Rather than fostering competition to provide people options and keep prices down, the federal government just pays the overpriced broadband services from cable companies. This form of corporate welfare, overpaying, is not generally discussed, but it is bankrupting the US federal government and many citizens, and its making US based business operations and citizens less competitive in the global market. Know that this is not due to politicians not wanting to help constituents. This is due to the high likelihood that if they try to lower the ridiculously high prices Americans pay, theyll be fought with many millions of dollars the industry will spend in ads against them, funds to their opponents, etc. Its not the politicians that are the problem, its the system theyre in. And thats why changing the politicians changes little in real life. The real change is media. They make money off the big Republican vs Democrat distraction. And they make a ton of money running ads for the corporations who love that Americans government pay multiples more than other rich people whose governments they cant do readily manipulate. Can you imagine any of them reporting that their advertisers are screwing Americans with the by far the highest prices in the world? All the people, citizens, business leaders, politicians, etc are doing the best they can within the system we have. If you want a system thats great for corporations in spite of their whining for more more more youve got it in the US, just look at the US stock markets and corporate profitability. But if you want a system great for citizens and US based business operations, well the US needs some major reforms.

replies.text: I cant speak for your situation but as a 35 year old, buying my first home was an amazing accomplishment and gave me great peace that I wouldnt have to apartment shop every few years or wait for new noisy neighbors or have my rent bumped every year.

1. A house is, first and foremost, a place to live. It might increase in value, it might not. But you will definitely pay a lot for it along the way. Taxes, insurance, maintenance...owning a home and keeping it in a condition where its sellable is a lot more than just principal and interest. 2. Along those lines, homes can be a terrible investment. Obviously, the one youre living in doesnt generally generate profit absent ADUs, etc.. But beyond that, they are among the most illiquid assets you can buy. They are geographically limited, with high transaction costs, etc. If I want to sell a stock, I click a button. If I want to sell my house, it could take a while. 3. At the end of the day, buy a house when youre ready to settle and buy a house. Dont buy just for the sake of buying.

I tell people this all the time, but your age and situation have a lot to do with it. If youre 25 and realistically just entered the workforce 23 years ago, youre going to be moving around and hopefully up in your career. No one stays at their first job for more than 23 years now and a lot of people are hopping around every 23 years especially early on for large pay raises and promotions. The issue with buying a house is it ties you down to a geographical location. Theres opportunity costs in only being able to accept positions within a reasonable commute to your house. For example, youre out job searching when its time for a moveupgrade and something paying a good 25 more with better benefits is on the other side of town and would make your commute jump from 3045 minutes to 1.5 hours each way. Do you take it? Suck it up? Try to sell the house and have to pay all the closing costs, moving, and other fees? If you were renting and more mobile, maybe its a 23 month fee and youre out, or perhaps youre cool with the landlord and theres no additional charge as long as you give a heads up of 12 months. Youre much more mobile. Point is, you buy a house when youre ready. Ideally with another person, like a wife or partner. Its bad enough we rent apartments as single people... buying a house single is even worse from a financial sense. All the expenses and upkeep are on you alone. Another financial thing to factor in are taxes and maintenancerepairs. Taxes are a lot these days and vary on area. Around here, taxes on a 300k house are actually more than our current rent. Taxes are essentially rent. so now youre paying a mortgage, have housing insurance, possibly PMI, interest to a bank... and youre paying rent taxes to the gooberment. Its expensive. Im in my mid30s and have had many friends buy houses. Nearly all of them cant attend events or do things on the weekend anymore. Why? XYZ project around the house. Maintenance. Cutting grass, painting, rebuilding retaining walls, fixing plumbing and other stuff. Its constant. Even when I lived with my parents I was constantly helping with projects. Dont want to input the time and effort? Cool, but then youre paying some professional to do it. So no, as a 25 year old, Id steer you clear of buying a house.

As a 25 year old, should buying a house be my first priority as an investment? No. It should be your last priority. The opportunity cost is too high Housing appreciates at 4.3 annually, while other assets like stocks appreciate at more like 10 annually. Or if we want real value, assuming 3 inflation, thats like 1.26 vs 6.8. The difference over long timespans is absurd, and every dollar you put into a house is a dollar you arent putting into those higher returning assets. Over the course of a 30 year mortgage, you can expect a house to go about 3.5x in value. But you could expect an index fund to grow about 17.5x in value. The cost of leverage ie. mortgage is too high. When mortgage rates were below 4.3, then you could reasonably expect to offset the leverage expense with gains in house price. Now, youre losing money on the deal. And paying it off early is just reducing leverage, so youre just transferring your losses from mortgage interest to losses from opportunity cost. The cost of ownership is probably higher than you think property tax, HOA, maintenance, home insurance, closing costs, etc.. Generally you save a lot by renting. The benefits from fixed mortgages tend to come in the second half of the mortgage, but taking a financial bath for 15 years is generally too big of a deficit to overcome, especially given current mortgage rates. Youre still at an age where you might move.... repeatedly. You can likely be more happy with renting a lessnice apartment than buying a lessnice house, because your commitment is generally only about a year. Which means you can save a lot more than even an apples to apples comparison. TLDR You should put off buying a home as long as possible and throw everything you can towards higher paying assets. Buying a home is fundamentally a conservative choice, and your risk appetite at age 25 should be much too high for buying a home. When to buy a home? Married with children. Nearing retirement and want to reduce risk profile Nonfinancial reasons, like you cant stand one more minute living in an apartment. You think youre living in an area that will absolutely explode in value, like Seattle 30 years ago. Theres some localized and temporary thing going on and buying is significantly cheaper than renting for some reason. Ballpark, 20 years rent is usually close to the price to buy. In some dying town, maybe its 10 years... but in a dying town, you probably wont get normal appreciation in home prices. But if for some reason there was an extreme but shortterm few years renting shortage, then maybe itd make sense. Youre really terrible at saving money so being forced to do it via your home is the only workable option for you.

Some general points for making it cost effective to buy a house You are planning to stay in the area 3 years. This lets you amortize the closing costs over a decent period You can house hack, where you rent out some portion of the house to cover your housing costs You can house hop, where you buy a run down house and bring it back to move in ready so its more marketable. Then sell and do again with a different house. This is effectively a second job that you can do at your own pace. Just make sure you are careful to do it right so it actually adds value. Generally you can only gain the difference in value between what is was vs the upgrade I.e you have to live with something unusable until you replace it Also the general formula for cost is Interest payment Taxes Maintenance Closing Costs to Buy Closing Costs to Sellyears of ownership Opportunity Cost on invested principal Appreciation Equity invested The years helps spread closing costs and lower amount of equity improves how much effective ROI you have from appreciation. Principal paid is not a cost since you keep that money, but it does have an opportunity cost could have been invested elsewhere. People compare mortgage to rent, but its not that simple. You need to do the math for your situation. Personal story We house hopped on a run down rental that someone offloaded. Ripped everything out kitchen, bathrooms, flooring and replaced. Refinanced and got enough cash out to put a down payment on a second home and kept the first. Now were renting our first, renovating our second long term, but bought in bad condition, and have an airbnb at the new house that covers half the mortgage.

Got my first place at 24. Paid the mortgage each month on time. My partner at the time rented out her place to cover her mortgage and contributed a proportion of the cost of mine while she lived so both of us paid less for accommodation than we would have individually and both had our mortgages paid. Prod, the real.estate value went up. The costs were a smaller proportion of each paycheck because mortgages with fixed repayments are not affected by inflation, but our paychecks went up as we became more senior. I paid the same proportion of my income and paid off the mortgage faster. Continued over payments reduce the actual mortgage costs in a compound manner too. Fast forward, yes there were fewer exotic vacations and less disposable income, but the house was paid off fast, the equity saved, the financial security and backing in place to move to bigger and better homes. Enjoy the 20s, or commit to a constant investment and enjoy your 40s with your own home and less debt.

Houses are not inherintly difficult to build on mass to keep up with demand. The issue lies in the legal and consent side, you need permission from the government to build a house or buy a plot. For these you often need loans, which adds an extra layer of permission from banks. Combined with zoning rules, material and architectural form requirements as per the neighbourhood district requirements, the area youre building, wealth or racial cock blocking you can only build houses at a certain minimum value in some areas, or an immigrant or minority cant develop an area because theyre a minority, etc. These parameters just add more layers. Some people have the funds to certainly build a house, but the costs and consents can be astronomical. Sometimes its for safety, like construction site safety and management. Safety does increase cost no doubt. Sometimes its due to speculation. Housing markets in cities in NZ, aussie, Canada, US, UK and most western euro countries, China in its major cities are inflated severely because housing is used as an investment vehicle rather than just a survival commodity. Forget about all the road blocks and points you mentioned, it wont change your decision. If youre smart and buy in a promosing area with good planning, strong community and work availability, great access to recreational areas, the area is safe lots of people around all the time, shops where people can watch your house all day, friendly neighbours and good community and the house is capable of flexible living conditions various pets, future children, can facilitate a large extended family, capable of being fitted for a home office or business etc., then regardless of what the circumstances are on a macro level, the house and plot are likely going to be stable and strong. Not necessarily explode In value, but they will be reliable because the essential tick boxes are there. When it comes to the house itself talk to an architect. They know houses better than anyone else and how to capture the most value out of it. I am an architect myself so I would know. For construction costs talk to builders. If you know none, find some. Get connections. For property value and price you can generally find that yourself as there are more than enough tools available. Real Estate agents are kinda useless these days.

Hi, 24yo m that bought a house at 23, heres some thoughts and what Id recommend. Houses in long run have proven to be good investments, so it is likely a solid financial decision to buy. With that said, they are a highmaintenance investment compared to something like stocks. ACs break, pipes burst, etc. These are all things that lower your roi, and are a pain in the bum. It is undoubtedly true that building equity is better than paying rent tho. Heres how I approached the problem I wanted a house so I could make more money in the long run, so I went out and looked for nice houses with many bedrooms. I made up a metric that was costbedroom, and tried to lower that as much as possible without sacrificing on quality of home. After I bought the house, I moved my friends in with me and they pay me rent. 4 of us in the house 4 bedrooms, I personally pay about 50month of my mortgage out of pocket. Obvi this is good because my cash flow situation is great, but there is risk with this. If my roommates were to leave, I would be on the hook for the full mortgage which is not cheap. The way to minimize this risk is to do a test of ur worst case scenario no roommates, how much are u spending every month in ur budget vs how much do u make. If u can afford to make all the payments and still eat, then ur prob ok. Having this extra income obvi helps in case u lose ur job or something too. Another thing about home ownership is the mortgage interest is tax deductible, so you may get a bit of a refund during tax season depending on ur situation, but if u are collecting rent u will have to pay taxes on that so be careful. obvi liquidity sucks compared to stocks, and u may have to increase size of ur emergency fund if mortgage is what u would pay for rent or something. as for the house itself, try to buy a nice house in a good location ik easier said than done lol but nice placeshomes tend to hold their value and are less volatile. youll have a very hard time selling a house if ur neighborhood sucks. look for a catalyst that will make ur home value go up. For me, I noticed a new homeless shelter was donated by rich people and is being built on other side of town. I live near current shelter, so if I own long enough eventually neighborhood becomes nicer when homeless population is relocated. Your location is of importance in this calculation, especially the housing supply in said location. I wouldnt buy in an area where tons of homes are being built, high supply equal low demand and prices. Its better to go to a neighborhood where all the houses are being fixed up full neighborhood finite supply than it is to go to a new neighborhood supply of houses increasing. last thing, I may be wrong about this dont buy a cookie cutter house. Ifwhen u go to sell it, you will likely be competing against other sellers that have the same house as you, and u will have to get into a price war to sell. Try to buy something unique again, lowers supply. lastly, your age is of concern. If u are young, there is a chance youll get a new job that will relocate you to a new city, and then your house could become a bit of a problem to maintain this is my current predicament. you can sell not what I want to do rn, get a property manager, expensive, I think only really good ones are worth it or try to maintain it yourself time consuming. If u are married andor have kids, I think buying a house makes more sense, for life reasons and because u are more likely to stay in ur city. sorry for rant hope this helps, pls lmk if any questions.

I strongly advise you to prepare to buy a house. Be modest in what you choose initially, and make sure you can comfortably afford it on an emergency salary whatever you think the floor of your earning potential is. I also recommend new construction so you have a fresh timer on things breaking due to age, plus a 1 year warranty for any nearterm issues. There are some astonishingly ignorant comments that suggest renting is better, but that wont set you up for success longterm. I watched my family rent for 30 years and they still dont own a house at retirement age. That means that even if they had saved properly which they didnt, they guaranteed themselves higher expenses in their old age. Not to mention that they paid someone elses mortgage and more during that 30 years, while the owner got their mortgage paid profit. I bought a house in 2020 smart and lucky and now pay 400 less on a mortgage for a 3 bedroom house than I paid for rent on a 1 bedroom apartment. Im up 100k in equity, and Ill never have to worry about rent getting raised or the owner deciding to sell. My payments will only shrink as I pay down the principal. If I lose my job and Im worried about money, I can rent a room to help offset the cost. If I move, I can rent or sell. Rates drop lower than what Im paying? Refinance. Major repair? Its absorbed by equity and my increased savingsinvestment ability. Meanwhile, I still have money to save, invest, travel, etc. Even more than if I was renting due to the cost difference. Also, this works with current rates too. Just depends where and what you buy. Theres a reason the American any many other nationalities dream includes owning a house. No one scrimps, saves, and slaves at their job with the goal of renting until they die. When you buy is up to you, but thats your best bet for longterm stability and financial agility. Sorry for the long comment, these other commenters got me fired up.

Hi, all these other comments are pretty gloomy. While housing prices do rise, Rental prices are rising much faster. When you find a place you like as a renter, the landlord has the right to increase the cost of rent every year. Unless you want to keep moving your monthly expenses are going to keep going up. Finding a home you love that you can afford can be challenging. I found one in LA back in 2004 and everyone said it was impossible. The home needed repairs but I got these done for under 10K and had a nice, relatively cheap place to live. My equity in my home doubled in 6 months. Fast forward to 2016 when I tried to buy something in a Southern state. I thought this would be simple as prices were cheaper and there was more inventory. It was still tough and the inventory was bought up quickly. I persisted and found a home I could afford. The mortgage was less than my rent in my crummy apartment. The value of my home went up 50 and keeps increasing. It is a matter of deciding what you want to buy, working out what you can afford, and then looking, looking, looking until you find your place. There are some expenses associated with owning a home but knowing you have a place that is yours to do what you wish with is a great feeling.

It is extremely dependent on current interest rates, _where_ you are looking to buy a house, and if you find value outside of pure monetary value in the house itself, how long the term of your mortgage is, etc. etc. For the OP in this thread, I think the answer to should buying a house be my first priority as an investment? is a pretty clear No. Perhaps buying a house should be a first priority in life if thats what brings you joy or comfort, but purely as an investment, no, just shove it in the SP 500 index funds and chill.

Youre misunderstanding what Im trying to communicate here. I am not arguing that real estate is a high risk investment. I am conducting a thought experiment where we try to come up with some of the worst qualities an investment can have. If we were to sit down and try to come up with some of the worst qualities you could find in an investment, what would some of those be? If I am offering you a generic investment in any asset that is illiquid, opaque, has transaction costs and is complex to sell, has high expenses even if you can estimate them, ties you to a geographical area, is leveraged at a high ratio of your income, is subject to damage from weather or natural disasters, and has low diversification, would you be rushing to buy it? Maybe, maybe not. Im not saying you cannot estimate the costs of a home or that it real estate is always a bad investment. But I am saying that its important to consider that real estate investment has a lot of qualities that many would consider to be quite negative.

Guys, if you are new to this sector, please read this message as a bit of advice from someone who has been in this investment since 2019. It is a volatile sector. Expect big drops of 20 in mid cap stocks and even more in small caps. Within a week. This happens also for the upside like we see this month for a lot of the U equities. That said, there is unbelievable valuation and immense upside to many uranium juniors and business focused on the fuel cycle enrichment etc. This sector moves at a glacial speed, and many stocks do get ahead of themselves. Do lots of homework on companies that are developers of mines. The only producers that need to be considered for a newbie is Cameco, Uranium energy Corp, boss energy and energy fuels. If you want more then look at Sprotts Uranium information on their website. Dont listen to hype on YouTube, X, and other sources. Its a great opportunity to buy a non fungible, scarce and undervalued commodity, but dont expect to make life changing money if you consider yourself an average investor, much of the easy money has been made already in the sitting and waiting. Now is the time to look for value, performance and the companies that are actually going to be able to mine this resources at significant quantities well into the future. Alongside the companies involved in the other services in the sector. This bull market is not a flash in the pan. This time for the nuclear industry, its game on.

Its true there is potential. The downside is that this industry is affected by world wide events. E.G. Fukushima. Prior to that westinghouse which was owned by Toshiba was forecasting a similar nuclear Renaissance. They began producing 4 AP1000 nuclear reactors 2 in SC, 2 in GA the nrc retroactively changed seismic requirements for the foundations of the reactors in the middle of construction. The 2 in SC were abandoned and comprise of a 20 billion dollar hole in the ground. This also forced westinghouse into chapter 11 bankruptcy and was sold by Toshiba. There are substantial risks, which are world wide, to the industry itself. Just to keep all potential investors aware.

Not a bad idea. Especially long term. Because current mineable uranium reserves cannot keep up with current demand much less future demand. As a civilization we probably have around 200 years of steadily increase uranium use before we run out and have to find a dramatically different source. If we were to convert half of the world to nuclear power wed have a decade or two. BUT... because its such a long term trend there is plenty of time to find alternatives, Thorium or ocean water extraction, and those alternatives will naturally bound the price as the price hits levels that are high enough to sustain this research.

The uranium market is already seeing a mix of tight supply and rising demand for nuclear energy, especially as countries push for clean energy solutions. Kazakhstans recent production cuts and the U.S. banning Russianenriched uranium are only going to add more pressure to an already constrained market. On top of that, demand for uranium is expected to grow as China and other nations continue to build nuclear reactors. Prices have been fluctuating, but many experts believe they will rise again due to these supply and demand dynamics. Whats also interesting is how big tech companies are now getting involved. Microsoft recently signed a deal to revive the Three Mile Island nuclear plant to power its data centers, while Oracle is building small modular reactors SMRs to fuel its AI data centers. Still waiting for liquid fluoride thorium reactor LFTR to come online. These can convert Thorium232 into Thorium233. This decays into Protactinium233, which further decays into Uranium233. Protactinium233 can be removed from the liquid salt of a tworegion MSR by reductive extraction into liquid bismuth. Basically a breeder reactor that uses a cheaper and more abundant fuel source. This style of reactor was designed in the 1950s and I honestly believe the main reason this hasnt been developed further is more due to proliferation risks than cost or feasibility. Since the Protactinium233 can be extracted rather easily and would be of high concentration, it would reduce a lot of the work needed to make a nuclear weapon. Mainly removal of neutron emitters and other purification steps to get to 95 purity of Uranium233. Uranium233 is a fissile isotope.

TL,DR from ChatGPT Summary Uranium Market Report Price Trends Since 2020, uranium prices have surged from 21lb to 106lb in February 2024, currently stabilizing at 83lb. The report suggests that this increase is only the beginning, with further growth expected. Uranium Overview Uranium is a naturally occurring radioactive metal, primarily used for nuclear energy. The key isotopes are U238 used in military applications and U235 used to fuel nuclear reactors. U235 is particularly efficient, with one kilogram producing energy equivalent to over 3 million pounds of coal. HALEU and Enrichment Highassay lowenriched uranium HALEU is critical for advanced nuclear reactors. The U.S. is investing in domestic HALEU production to reduce reliance on imports, especially from Russia, which controls a significant portion of global enrichment capacity. The U.S. has started producing HALEU domestically, supported by government initiatives. Supply Challenges Uranium supply is tightening due to depleted inventories and underinvestment in mining. Mines are expensive and slow to develop, often taking 1015 years to become operational. The market is shifting to rely more on primary mining as secondary supplies dwindle. Primary production is forecasted to decrease by 30 by 2035, highlighting a potential supply gap. Demand Growth The U.S., China, and France account for 58 of global uranium demand. As of 2024, there are 440 operating reactors worldwide, with many more planned. The World Nuclear Association predicts a 28 increase in demand from 20232030 and a 51 rise from 20312040, driven by global clean energy goals. Global Production Kazakhstan is the leading producer, supplying 43 of global uranium. However, production cuts due to delays and shortages could put further pressure on prices. The U.S. has also increased its domestic uranium production in 2024, signaling a shift toward selfreliance. Investment Insights The report suggests that mining companies are wellpositioned to benefit from rising uranium prices. Companies like Cameco, NexGen Energy, and ETFs such as URNM and NUKZ are highlighted as investment opportunities. Big tech companies like Amazon and Google are also investing in nuclear energy, emphasizing the growing interest in this sector. Conclusion The report anticipates a bullish market for uranium due to increasing demand and limited supply. With countries seeking clean energy and reducing carbon emissions, uraniums role as a key energy source is set to grow, potentially driving prices to unprecedented levels. Global turnover in U is pretty large but a rather small share of it ever meaningfully sees the market. The industry is vertically integrated to an incredibly high degree. A given mine might be in Canada, but it is owned by a consortium of utilities that ultimately use the metal and the price is just an exercise in accounting, the actual cost to the utilities being their share of the wages and operation costs of the mine, because while they might Buy the U, that amounts to taking money out of their left pocket and putting it into the right one. This means that mines opening up or closing that do sell on the open U market can swing the price like mad. It doesnt matter to most of the industry.

Invest my savings you should talk to a financial advisor. However, Ill give you the benefit of the doubt that you already have 6 months of actual savings in case of an emergency. However, Im curious now what is the first thing you do with your paycheck what do you do with the money first for it savings wise like where do you put it first.

The income that I live off of comes from trading in the stock market that I do using leverage collateralized by my savings. If I instead put those savings into a house, I lose that collateral and therefore my ability to trade on margin. So, Id have to start working normal hours again to replace that income source. Its just the nature of the Los Angeles real estate market, the buy vs rent equation always depends on the specific market youre in. Where I live, you simply cant just put 20 down and expect to get a mortgage that costs the same as what the rent for that place would be. So my options would be assuming I want to maintain my current standard of living or at least close to it 1 Go back to work while still maintaining my current trading activities in order to double my income, then put 20 down on a condohouse and get a mortgage which with current interest rates is going to be almost double my current rent for the rest. Or 2 Buy a condohouse in cash using all of my savings, and go back to work to fund all of my other expenses and build back up some savings. Either way, Id have to go back to working full time and I have additional financial concerns with both options on top of that. And of course, it was because of renting and rent control that I was able to invest so much of my old salary in the first place, making my current situation possible. Needless to say, there are a lot of factors in my situation that are unique to me personally, but everyone where I live is faced with the issue that buying requires a far higher monthly cash outflow than renting for a comparable place.

My last paycheck was 269 for the month of September. Like I said, I invested my money over the years instead of buying a house. That has allowed me to now not work much. If I bought a house, Id have to start working full time again. Dealbreaker. To each their own.

So you dont invest in a Roth IRA? Investments are fine and all but Roth is a staple for retirement because you dont pay taxes on what you withdrawal. You pay taxes before you invest it which is nice because if taxes go up in the future you paid less tax to invest. If you invest just through a brokerage you are using money you paid tax on then when you withdraw you pay tax on capital gains so you get taxed twice and around 40 overall. If you invest in Apple or something of the likes that is solely a business and not an etf that pays out dividends you dont pay tax on said dividends however any money you make from dividends like from investing in SPY or even a savings account gets taxed.

OP is holding bags. The techniques they use to protect the system are the simpliest ... mainly blacklists and whitelists. Thats ignoring XDRs machine learning, behavioral analytics, device protection profiles, the fact that you can ingest firewall alerts into XDR, etc. Oh wow you can completely bypass AV as an admin!? BlackHat speaker was basically farming career karma for explaining how a product works, which good for him, probably looks great on his resume. NGAVs. They all work relatively the same. They all rely on MITRE techniques tactics and procedures along with IOCs to blockalert on bad behavior. The idea that one company has secret sauce when malware has relied on many of the same fundamental software vulnerabilities for decades is rediculous and I will die on that hill. I have used both CS and XDR. Both have pros and cons.

The threat model might be limited yeah but again to me its just an example of how poor ONE of their product is, think about the rest if they build stuff this way. Cortex literally showing you what regex it uses to prevent you from executing a command? Like how they dont know you shouldnt show this info? All of configuration files in plain sight that basically reveals the internals of the product.

Their PANOS has a long history of being a source of vulnerabilities that were exploited You can say this to all companies selling appliances NetApp, HPE, Cisco, Juniper, Check Point,... The thing is they all run Linux bundled with lots of ancient packages that have CVEs showing ups all the time. Enterprises and security pentest shops perform scanning regularly plus monitor CVE database, once anything shows up theyll turn their attention to appliances they own and publish reports. Not to say their stock is overpriced or not, I no longer follow this market closely.

Customer and revenue means that they are good at selling it and their product is good. You dont get to their level without a good product. One vulnerability in a module that represents 10 of their revenue is not enough to predict a market change. Again, youre just shilling S and its super clear.

Buy post puts or gtfo. I read 1 paragraph of the DD before giving up. But GPT read and responded in 5seconds The critique youve provided rests on a few misconceptions and overlooks key aspects of AIs current trajectory and potential. 1. AI Approaches and Progress The critique dismisses the GPTML approach as a known dead end, but this perspective fails to account for the significant advancements these methods have already achieved. While its true that current AI systems are not equivalent to human intelligence or capable of fulfilling science fictionlike fantasies e.g., J.A.R.V.I.S., this was never their immediate goal. The successes of GPT3, GPT4, and similar models in natural language processing, image generation, and other domains are impressive and provide immense value across industries. 2. Exponential Investment for Linear Gains The notion of exponential investment for linear gains is not unique to AI. Most technological progress, particularly in nascent fields, requires substantial investment before significant breakthroughs are realized. The idea that AI is stagnating is contradicted by ongoing improvements in model capabilities, optimization techniques, and the emergence of new architectures that continue to push the boundaries of whats possible. 3. Business Case for AI The critique argues that AI has failed to meet investor expectations by not delivering a fully autonomous system capable of complex tasks like designing cars. However, this expectation misunderstands the nature of AI development. AI is not meant to be an allencompassing solution to every problem overnight. Incremental improvements, such as automating specific tasks, enhancing decisionmaking, and creating new products, are already transforming industries. The ultimate goals may be ambitious, but the journey itself is valuable and profitable. 4. Training Data and Resources Concerns about running out of training data or resources ignore the adaptability of AI research. Techniques like transfer learning, unsupervised learning, and more efficient model architectures help mitigate these challenges. Moreover, the development of specialized hardware, improved algorithms, and better data utilization strategies continuously address the resourceintensive nature of AI. 5. Nvidias Role While its true that tech giants are moving towards vertical integration, Nvidia remains a critical player in the AI hardware ecosystem. The dominance of CUDA, the ongoing innovation in GPU architecture, and the importance of a robust softwarehardware ecosystem are not easily replaced or replicated. Nvidias role may evolve, but it is far from obsolete. 6. Investor Expectations The critique implies that investors are disillusioned, yet the continued flow of capital into AI suggests otherwise. While there may be some adjustments as the field matures, the broader trajectory of AI investment remains strong, driven by both immediate applications and longterm potential. In summary, while AIs development is complex and requires tempered expectations, dismissing the entire field as a bubble fails to appreciate the genuine advancements and ongoing potential that AI, particularly machine learning, continues to unlock.

Because they are investing in the next wave of labor replacements for the said trillions of future revenue? It turns out you need to invest now to see revenue later. You are also wrong about improvement costs being completely exponential. That is true for the scaling wide increasing parameter count and training time, but scaling vertically is much more efficient. I use the latest models every day for programming and it seems like every week theres something new that can solve some problems the previous model couldnt solve. The current state of the art is focused on improving training and making a corpus of training data have better results. The gains are spectacular. Microsofts Phi 3.5 mini came out last week and has 3.8B parameters. It outperforms Llama 2 70B from a year ago on benchmarks. Thats almost 20x less parameters and possibly training time. They did this by improving training methodology and making training data higher quality. So methodology is leading to huge improvements. Hyper scale companies are continuing to scale wide AND implement these methodologies. This means each generation is getting better and better and we have a while before we get to scraping the bottom of the barrel of the gains.

Sams talking about burning 50 billion a year to build AGI and its just got people wondering how many rounds well have to go on this before we get whats actually promised. At the end of the day its not his 50 billion to burn, his company isnt profitable so its gotta come from other people who arent going to keep ponying up if theres no progress to show for it. Obviously the AI sector is bigger than OpenAI, but theyre the best example. True AGI would be worth near infinite investment, but 400B for the current state of AI wasnt worth it, the longer this goes the more investors will just see it as throwing good money after bad.

Thats untrue. A TSMC 300mm wafer costs around 20.000. Its area is Pi 150mm2 70.650mm2. The Die size of an Intel Core 14900K is around 257mm2, which means Intel gets 70.650mm2 257mm2 275 chips out of a wafer. Assuming they are all good which they arent, a single 14900k would cost 20.000 275 73 to manufacture. Since most of the chips will have some sort of defect, the actual price is way higher.

Theres a big difference between paying the taxes you owe according to tax law, and doing something unethicalimmoral. Our tax system contains many provisions that can be used to align your wealth more closely with your goals while also reducing the amount owed to the government. This is by design, as the government wants to incentivize certain behaviors. A lot of folks think these methods are only for the rich, but the reality is most of us can benefit from them in the same way. Ask yourself, would you choose to pay 15 effective tax, or 12 effective tax? Do you voluntarily pay more tax than you think you owe? If not, then reducing your tax burden via completely legal and intended mechanisms might be worth considering.
